High energy-density hydrocarbon fuels are the key materials for aircraft to increase payload and expand flight distance. Under the catalysis of atomically dispersed Pd(0) complex, saturated hexacyclic exo-exo product with good fuel property can be synthesized via co-dimerization of norbornadiene (NBD) with quadricyclane (QC). But the fragile coordination state of homogeneous Pd(0) complex limited its application in fuel production. In this work, Pd(0) complex has been heterogeneously supported on silica support with the regulation of polyethylene glycol (PEG) to increase its stability and recyclability with limited sacrifice of the activity and dimer selectivity. The structure of silica support was tuned to achieve the proper interaction with PEG and Pd(0) complex. The chain length and concentration of PEG were adjusted to further optimize the state of Pd(0) complex on silica. The as-developed heterogeneous Pd(0) complex supported on dendritic mesoporous silica nanospheres regulated by PEG2000 exhibited superior performance for the production of high energy density fuel through selective NBD-QC co-dimerization. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Norbornadiene Quadricyclane Pd(0) complex Heterogeneous High density fuel 1 Introduction In recent years, with the rapid development of aviation industry, there is an urgent need for high energy density fuels [1–4]. High energy-density hydrocarbon fuels are essential for aircraft to increase payload and expand flight distance. The hydrocarbon molecules with multiple bridge rings are good candidates for developing new fuels with tunable properties. Some norbornadiene (NBD) dimers possess highly caged structure, high energy density and large volumetric net heat of combustion (NHOC), which attract more and more attentions [5–10]. These dimers have been mainly produced through cycloaddition reaction of NBD. Owing to the unique bridged ring structure of NBD, its dimerization generates a wide range of isomeric mixtures as shown in Scheme 1, depending on the type of the catalyst employed in the reaction [11–20]. At present, the hydrogenated hexacyclic endo-endo NBD dimer (HHnn) is widely used in the field of high energy density fuels, such as the famous jet propellant RJ-5 [1, 12, 21]. Hexacyclic exo-exo NBD dimer (Hxx), possessing good properties, was hardly synthesized with high yield [5]. A significant improvement was made by Acton and co-workers [6, 22] in 1972. They detected Hxx for the first time in NBD solution under the catalysis of [(C6H5)3P]3RhCl. Subsequently, James et al. [23] found that Hxx could be prepared with a high selectivity in the Co(acac)3-Diphos-DEAC system. But the reaction conditions were harsh and the yield of Hxx was low. In addition, Dzhemilev et al. [24–26] found that zero-valent metal palladium (Pd(0)) complex exhibited excellent activity in cycloaddition of NBD. Co-dimerization of NBD and quadricyclane (QC) catalyzed by Pd(0) complex gave Hxx and other polymers yield of greater than 85%. The homogeneous Pd(0) complex is unstable and hardly separated from reaction mixture [27, 28]. Thus, when Pd(0) complex is used as the catalyst, the production cost of NBD dimers will be increased to a high extent [5, 6]. In comparison, heterogeneous catalyst will be a good choice for co-dimerization of NBD and QC, since it is easily recovered and reused [29–35]. The Pd(0) complex can be supported on organic macromolecules such as dendrimer, ligand-incorporated polymer and copolymer [36–40]. It can also be loaded on inorganic supports [41, 42]. Zeolite, amorphous silicate, silica and other oxides exhibit extensive prospect in terms of loading Pd(0) complex for the co-dimerization of NBD and QC [43–47]. SBA-15 and dendritic mesoporous silica nanospheres (DMSNs) with higher affinity for Pd(0) were usually employed. However, ligand leaching was observed due to the instability of the Pd-ligand bond or the weak bonding of the ligand on support surface, leading to quick deactivation. To maintain a high activity, Pd(0) atom should be weakly coupled with the ligand. The active and fragile Pd-ligand structure will be destroyed when Pd(0) complex is directly loaded on the solid support, which is a major difficulty to be overcome for developing active and stable heterogeneous catalysts of Pd(0) complex [44–50]. Polyethylene glycol (PEG) with unique CO-C structure and tunable spatial configuration showed suitable coordination ability to metal complex for many catalytic applications [51–56]. Herein, PEG has been introduced and adjusted to stably load Pd(0) complex on matched silica support for the well-maintained activity in NBD-QC co-dimerization. Various inorganic silica supports, including gas phase silica gel (PS), DMSNs and SBA-15, were employed to load Pd(0) complex for enhanced stability, good recycling performance and well-maintained activity. The molecular weight of PEG was changed to regulate its coordination with Pd(0) complex and to tune its interaction with the support. Both reactant conversion and dimer selectivity on those catalysts were analyzed. An optimized catalyst (Pd-0.5PEG2000/DMSNs) with superior performance has been developed. Finally, a reaction mechanism has been proposed in order to rationalize these findings. 2 Experimental 2.1 Chemicals Norbornadiene (NBD), quadricyclane (QC) and Pd2(dba)3•CHCl3 were purchased from Macklin. Gas phase silica gel (PS), dendritic mesoporous silica nanospheres (DMSNs) and SBA-15 were bought from Nanjing xianfeng nano technology Co. The commercial catalyst of Pd/Al2O3 with a Pd content of 5 wt% was purchased from Shanghai xianding biotechnology Co. PEGs with different molecular weights, tetrahydrofuran (THF), N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF) and dimethyl sulfoxide (DMSO) were bought from Kermel. All chemicals were used as received without any purification. 2.2 Catalyst preparation Firstly, 1.00 g of inorganic support (PS, DMSNs or SBA-15) was added into 30 mL of ethanol with magnetic stirring at room temperature, and the mixture was stirred for 3 h. Subsequently, 0.0333 mmol of Pd2(dba)3•CHCl3 and 0.5 mL of PEG were successively dissolved in 1.00 mL of ethanol with magnetic stirring. Then, the solution was dropped into above support-ethanol solution at room temperature, and the mixture was stirred for 3 h. Finally, the product was treated in rotary evaporator to remove the solvent by gradually increasing the temperature from 30 °C to 60 °C. Then, the obtained sample was dried in vacuum at 60 °C for 6 h. The as-synthesized catalyst was denoted as Pd-nPEGx/support, in which n is the amount of PEG (mL) and x is the molecular weight of PEG. The content of Pd in the sample was 0.69% as determined by inductively coupled plasma-optical emission spectroscopy (ICP-OES). 2.3 Catalyst characterization X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were collected on a X-ray diffract meter equipped with a Cu Kα radiation source in the 2θ range (D/MAX2500PC, Rigaku). Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FT-IR) of the catalyst was measured by an Infrared spectrometer (Vertex 70). X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was performed on a Thermo ESCALAB 250Xi instrument with monochromatic Al Kα radiation at ambient temperature, and the C1s line at 284.8 eV was used as the binding energy reference. Morphology and microstructure of the catalysts were investigated by scanning electron microscope (SEM, Hitachi S-4800). Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) was conducted on JEOL JEM-F200. N2 adsorption-desorption isotherm was analyzed by Micromeritics TriStar 3000. Prior to each measurement, all samples were degassed at 120 °C for 23 h. The specific surface area was calculated using Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) equation. The pore size distribution was determined from the entire desorption branch based on the Barrett-Joyner-Halenda (BJH) algorithm. Inductively coupled plasma optical emission spectrometry (ICP-OES) measurements were carried out on a VISTA-MPX EL02115765 instrument. Gas chromatography (GC, SHIMADZU 2010 plus) and GC with mass spectrometry (GC-MS, Agilent 5975/7890) were employed to monitor the reaction conversion and selectivity. Nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) spectra were recorded with a Bruker AMX 500 MHz instrument. 1H and 13C chemical shifts (δ) were given in ppm, and CDCl3 was used as the solvent for NMR spectroscopy. 2.4 Co-dimerization of NBD and QC Co-dimerization of NBD and QC was carried out in a 100 mL 2-neck round bottomed flask. The flask was charged with 1.00 g of supported metal catalyst, 30 mL of n-hexane, and 1 mL of dodecane (internal standard). The flask was then immersed in an oil bath that was maintained at 110 °C. 10 mmol of QC and 20 mmol of NBD were added slowly by two 5 mL syringes at the reaction temperature. The reaction proceeded for 3 h under N2 atmosphere, and the products were collected and analyzed by GC and GC-MS [22]. 2.5 Hot filtration test The hot filtration test was applied by filtering the reaction mixture using a pre-heated celite pad after the reaction for 1 h. The filtrate was detected by GC. Then, the filtrate was stirred under reaction temperature (110 °C) for 2 h, and was analyzed by GC again to determine the yield of Hxx. 2.6 Product purification and hydrogenation The reaction fluid was filtered using a sand core filter with an oil filter film. Subsequently, a certain amount of anhydrous magnesium sulfate was added to the filtered solution, and the mixture was stirred overnight to remove moisture from the sample. After filtration, a certain amount of silica gel was added into the sample, and the mixture was stirred for 3 h to adsorb the residual metal catalyst in the sample. Then, silica gel was removed by filtration. Finally, the solvent and other low-boiling impurities in the sample were removed by vacuum distillation. 1.2 L of Hxx with a purity of 98% was obtained. Hydrogenation of Hxx was conducted in a 100 mL stainless autoclave with 70 g of Hxx as the feedstock and 1.0 g of Pd/Al2O3 as the catalyst. Air was replaced by pure N2, and the reactor was pressured by hydrogen at a pressure of 4 MPa. Then, the reactor was heated to 70 °C and maintained for 30 min. After reaction, the hydrogenated product was purified following a similar procedure for the treatment of Hxx. The obtained fuel was named as HHxx. As analyzed by GC and GC-MS, the purity of the hydrogenated Hxx in the product was 98%. 2.7 Fuel properties Heat of combustion of as-prepared fuel was measured in an oxygen bomb calorimeter (IKA C6000). Freezing point of the product was determined by a low temperature viscosity thermostat. Density of the product was measured by a Mettler Toledo DE40 density meter, and viscosity of the product was measured using a capillary viscometer at −20 °C, 0 °C and 20 °C. 3 Results and discussion Fig. 1 displays the XRD patterns of five as-prepared catalysts, in which Pd2(dba)3 was loaded on different silica supports and regulated by different PEGs. All catalysts exhibit the characteristic diffraction peak of silica at 20° In addition, two sharp diffraction peaks were detected in three catalysts, Pd-0.5PEG2000/DMSNs, Pd-0.5PEG2000/PS and Pd-0.5PEG2000/SBA-15, in which PEG2000 was used as the regulator. The characteristic diffraction peak of Pd was not observed, indicating the well-maintained Pd(0) complex during catalyst preparation. Typical SEM images of the catalysts at different magnifications are presented in Fig. 2 . The three types of silica support (DMSNs, PS, SBA-15) were compared for loading Pd2(dba)3 with the regulation of different PEGs (PEG600 and PEG2000). All samples were composed of small primary particles of nanometer scale. Pd-0.5PEG2000/DMSNs maintained the star-shaped structure of the silica microspheres. In comparison, the star-shaped structure was not detected in the spherical particles of Pd-0.5PEG600/DMSNs. It can be deduced that PEGs with different chain lengths indeed interact differently with DMSNs to modify their morphology. In addition, both PS and SBA-15 retained their original structures after the loading of Pd(0) complex in the presence of PEG. TEM images of these catalysts are shown in Fig. 3 . The star shape of Pd-0.5PEG2000/DMSNs with a size of about 80 nm was revealed in Fig. 3a. Some Pd metal nanoparticles are uniformly distributed on the silica microspheres, the size of which is mainly between 3 nm and 5 nm. It can be deduced that a portion of Pd2(dba)3 decomposed after being loaded on DMSNs with the protection of PEG2000. Without the stabilization of dba ligands, those unstable Pd(0) atoms aggregated to form large particles. The mapping results further confirm this deduction as shown in Fig. 3b. Fig. 3c and Fig. 3d show the typical TEM images of Pd-0.5PEG2000/PS and Pd-0.5PEG2000/SBA-15, respectively. The original morphology of the supports, PS and SBA-15, has been well maintained after the introduction of Pd2(dba)3 on their surfaces, which is consistent with the SEM results. Many large metal particles were observed, demonstrating serious agglomeration of Pd metal after loading. A large number of Pd2(dba)3 was destroyed during catalyst preparation, and the dissociated Pd atoms with high surface energy seriously aggregated. With the damage of Pd2(dba)3 and the agglomeration of Pd on silica support, the catalytic activity of the catalysts will be inhibited, and the selectivity will be greatly altered. N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms and corresponding pore size distributions for the as-prepared catalysts are shown in Fig. 4 . The isotherm is a type IV hysteresis loop according to the IUPAC categorization. Different mesoporous structures are present in these catalysts. Pd-0.5PEG2000/DMSNs and Pd-0.5PEG600/DMSNs exhibit similar hysteresis loops owing to their inherent structure of dendritic mesoporous silica nanosphere. For Pd-0.5PEG2000/PS, the mesopores originated from the stacking of PS particles. Pd-0.5PEG2000/SBA-15 exhibited typical N2 adsorption-desorption isotherm of SBA-15. BET surface area, pore volume and pore diameter of the catalysts were calculated, and the data are summarized in Table 1 . When SBA-15 was used as the support, the as-prepared Pd-0.5PEG2000/SBA-15 possessed the highest surface area of 237.9 m2/g and the largest pore volume of 0.63 cm3/g. When Pd2(dba)3 was loaded on DMSNs by the regulation of different PEGs, the obtained catalysts (Pd-0.5PEG2000/DMSNs and Pd-0.5PEG600/DMSNs) exhibited lower surface area and smaller pore volume compared with the catalysts using PS or SBA-15 as the support (Pd-0.5PEG2000/PS and Pd-0.5PEG2000/SBA-15). Moreover, PEG2000 with higher molecular weight on DMSNs leaded to a lower BET surface area (25.8 m2/g) than that using PEG600 (36.1 m2/g). Pore volume of Pd-0.5PEG2000/DMSNs is slightly lower than that of Pd-0.5PEG600/DMSNs, even though their average pore diameter is at the same level. It indicates that some pores of DMSNs were blocked by long-chain PEG2000. FT-IR spectra of the as-synthesized catalysts were recorded, and the results are displayed in Fig. 5 a. In all the four samples, the peak at 1640 cm−1 was mainly caused by the deformation vibration of C=C of Pd2(dba)3. The peak at 3340 cm−1 can be attributed to the -OH groups of water or PEG. The absorption peaks of -CH2 groups were detected at 1465 cm−1 and 2893 cm−1. The -CH2 peaks of the catalyst prepared by DMSNs as the support are relatively sharp. It can be explained by the presence of some residual precursors in DMSNs. The FT-IR spectra of PEG2000, Pd-0.5PEG2000 and Pd-0.5PEG2000/DMSNs are compared in Fig. 5b. The peaks at 1088 cm−1 and 795 cm−1 were assigned to the asymmetric and symmetrical stretching vibration of Si-O-Si, respectively, which could be attributed to the characteristic absorption bands of DMSNs. The peak at 1112 cm−1 is assigned to the CO-C structure in PEG. This peak shifts to a lower wavenumber of 1103 cm−1 in Pd-0.5PEG2000/DMSNs with Pd2(dba)3 and PEG2000 loaded on DMSNs, which indicates that a part of CO-C in PEG2000 is vibrationally coupled with Si-O-Si in DMSNs [57, 58]. XPS spectra were collected to determine the state Pd after being loaded on the support. The XPS Pd core level region of Pd2(dba)3 directly loaded on DMSNs (Pd/DMSNs) is shown in Fig. 6 a. The peaks at around 334.8 eV and 340.5 eV are assigned to Pd(0) on a particle, and the peaks at around 337.0 eV and 342.6 eV are assigned to Pd(II) in the oxidation state. The composition of different Pd species in various heterogeneous catalysts was calculated, and the results are summarized in Table 2 . When Pd2(dba)3 was directly loaded on DMSNs without any protection, no coordinated Pd(0) was detected. All complexes with Pd(0) in single-atom state were destroyed to generate a large amount of particles containing Pd(0) (71.78%) and Pd(II) (28.22%). During the loading of Pd2(dba)3 on DMSNs, the fragile coordination bonds of Pd2(dba)3 was broken, and those sensitive and separated Pd(0) atoms easily aggregated into large particles, some of which were oxidized to Pd(II) by air. With the addition of 0.5 mL PEG2000 during loading Pd2(dba)3 on DMSNs, the state of Pd species on DMSNs was greatly changed. In addition to the Pd(0) particles, a new Pd(0) peak appeared in the spectrum, which is attributed to the single-atom Pd(0) in the original coordination state of Pd2(dba)3. 28.19% of those coordinated single-atom Pd(0) were retained on Pd-0.5PEG2000/DMSNs. The fraction of aggregated Pd(0) particles was decreased from 71.78% to 62.01%. In addition, the content of Pd(II) (9.8%) in Pd-0.5PEG2000/DMSNs was significantly decreased by the regulation of PEG2000 compared with that in Pd/DMSNs without any regulation. Two functions have been effectively realized by PEG2000 as the regulator during the loading of Pd2(dba)3 on DMSNs, preventing Pd(0) aggregation to avoid the formation of Pd(0) particles and inhibiting Pd(0) oxidation to suppress the generation of Pd(II). When the amount of PEG2000 or PEG600 were decreased to 0.05 mL, the content of Pd(II) was almost unchanged, while the amount of Pd(0) particles was greatly increased. It demonstrates that a small amount of PEGs can still effectively prevent the oxidation of Pd(II). But the aggregation of Pd(0) atoms was hardly suppressed in such condition. In comparison, when 0.5 mL of PEG200 or PEG600 were used, the amount of Pd(0) particles was almost unchanged, while the content of Pd(II) was greatly increased compared with that of PEG2000. It can be deduced that PEG200 and PEG600 with small chain length hardly prevent the oxidation of Pd(0), leading to decreased content of coordinated Pd(0). In conclusion, a long chain length of PEG was requisite for inhibiting the oxidation of Pd(0) formation, and a small amount of the PEG will work. The amount of PEG must be adequate to prevent the formation of Pd(0) particles, in which the molecular weight of PEG has little impact. For maintaining the coordinated single-atom Pd(0), both a long chain length and an adequate concentration of PEG are required. As reported previously, the active species for catalyzing NBD-QC co-dimerization is the coordinated Pd(0) complex, and the isomerization reaction of QC to NBD is more likely to occur on Pd(II) sites [26]. Thus, it can be inferred that the addition of suitable PEG2000 for maintaining the coordinated Pd(0) on silica support is beneficial to the co-dimerization of NBD and QC. Co-dimerization of NBD and QC was carried out on different catalysts to evaluate their performance, and the results are shown in Fig. 7 . The catalytic activities are in the order of Pd-0.5PEG600/DMSNs > Pd-0.5PEG2000/DMSNs > Pd-0.5PEG2000/PS > Pd-0.5PEG2000/SBA-15 > Pd-0.5PEG200/DMSNs. On all the catalysts, 100% conversion of QC was reached, and the selectivity of Hxx was maintained at a level of over 93%. When Pd-0.5PEG 2000/DMSNs was used as the catalyst, the conversion of NBD reached 35.63%, which is significantly higher than those on Pd-0.5PEG2000/PS (15.12%) and Pd-0.5PEG 2000/SBA-15 (26.46%). The results reveal that the structure of silica greatly affects the catalytic activity through its interaction with the Pd(0) complex. To further verify our conclusion, pure silicon KIT-6, MCM-41, and solid silica spheres (300-500 nm), were also used as the support to load Pd2(dba)3. No co-dimerization product of NBD and QC was detected in the reaction. Therefore, it can be concluded that suitable environment can be provided by DMSNs to achieve properly interaction with PEG and Pd2(dba)3 for stably loading separated Pd(0) atoms. In addition, the chain length of PEG plays a key role on constructing optimized microenvironment to protect and retain the fragile Pd2(dba)3. When PEG200 was employed, the conversion of NBD sharply dropped to 8.03%. In comparison, the NBD conversions were 37.25% and 35.63% on the catalysts regulated by PEG600 and PEG2000, respectively. The results can be well explained by the contents of coordinated Pd(0) in the catalysts. As determined by XPS, Pd-0.5PEG200/DMSNs contained only 19.66% of coordinated Pd(0), which was 28.19% in Pd-0.5PEG2000/DMSNs and 25.92% in Pd-0.5PEG600/DMSNs. Scheme 2 compares the catalytic performance of Pd-0.5PEG2000/DMSNs with those reported previously for the synthesis of NBD dimers. When three-component homogeneous catalytic system [23, 59] containing Co(acac)3 or Fe(acac)3, DEAC and Diphos was used for catalytic cycloaddition of NBD, the total yield of Hxx and other dimers was very low (Scheme 2a). Subsequently, the applications of HY, HBeta, HZSM-5, Al-MCM-41, KIT-6 zeolites [60] and Co/HY [61] in NBD dimerization were carried out as shown in Scheme 2b. The advantages of the heterogeneous catalysts are their low cost and good reusability. However, the distribution of NBD dimers was too complex to be fully identified and the reaction conditions were harsh. These reactions generally produced a complex mixture with many other isomeric byproducts, and the overall yield of NBD dimers were 30%−50% due to the poor selectivity. In this work, when NBD and QC were used as the reactants, the yield of Hxx reached 80.12% (Scheme 2c). Therefore, the Pd-0.5PEG2000/DMSNs system exhibits superior performance for the synthesis of Hxx. The influence of metal precursor on catalytic activity and selectivity was also investigated. When Pd(OAc)2 with wholly Pd(II) was loaded on DMSNs in the presence of PEG2000, no dimer was detected in the reaction product, but a large amount of QC was transformed into NBD. It demonstrates that isomerization of QC to NBD is more likely to occur on Pd(II) sites, which is in good agreement with previous results [26]. Three Pd(0) complexes, including Pd2(dba)3, Pd2(dba)3•CHCl3, and Pd(PPh3)4, have been compared. A similar procedure for the synthesis of Pd-0.5PEG2000/DMSNs was employed for loading these Pd precursors, in which DMSNs was the support and 0.5 mL of PEG2000 was added. As shown in Fig. 8 a, all the catalysts prepared by the three Pd(0) complexes exhibit excellent catalytic activity. More than 35% of NBD was converted on the three catalysts. Supported Pd(PPh3)4 showed superior performance, on which the conversion of NBD reached 40% and the selectivity of Hxx was as high as 94%. Pd(PPh3)4 is very sensitive to air at room temperature, and the catalyst will quickly deactivate when exposed to air [62]. When Pd(PPh3)4 was loaded on DMSNs with the addition of PEG2000, the stability of the catalyst was significantly improved and the activity was well retained. After being placed in air for a period of time, the catalyst of supported Pd(PPh3)4 still possessed high activity. It further confirms the excellent performance of PEG with suitable chain length as a robust regulator for stabilizing Pd(0) complex on the silica support. PEG is a nontoxic, low-cost and recyclable polymer with a very wide average molecular weight distribution (from PEG200 to PEG100W). In the future, a variety of physicochemical properties of PEG will be adjusted to fully play its role of stabilizing metal active species on silica support [54]. The effect of solvent on the activity and selectivity of Pd-0.5PEG2000/DMSNs was investigated. As shown in Fig. 8b, the solvent also had a great influence on the conversion of NBD. When non-polar n-hexane was used, the NBD conversion was 35.63%. When polar solvent was used, NBD conversion sharply dropped. In THF or DMF, no NBD was converted. Because polar solvent has a certain coordination ability, which will compete with QC in the coordination with Pd(0) sites. The influences of solvent amount and reaction temperature on the catalytic activity and selectivity were studied, and the results are presented in Fig. 8c and d. On increasing the solvent from 10 mL to 50 mL, the selectivity of Hxx was stably maintained to a high value of >98%, but NBD conversion was constantly decreased from 38.26% to 8.98%. Because too many solvent molecules may weaken the coordination between QC and Pd(0). In addition, the conversion of NBD was sharply increased from 8.14% to 35.63% by the increase of temperature from 60 °C to 110 °C. In order to investigate the stability and reusability, Pd-0.5PEG2000/DMSNs was recycled and evaluated in QCNBD co-dimerization for additional three times, and the reaction results are shown in Fig. 9 . New reactants were constantly added in the solution, and the reaction was conducted under the same conditions. After the first cycle, the conversion of NBD was slightly decreased, and a NBD conversion of more than 20% was well maintained in latter cycles. During the experiments, the conversion of QC was kept at 95%−100%, and the selectivity of Hxx was maintained at a value of more than 90%. The results reveal that Pd-0.5PEG2000/DMSNs possesses good stability and reusability. Hot filtration test is a widely applied method to investigate the nature of the catalyst. The hot filtration test of the reaction mixture was executed, and the reaction data are given in Table 3 . The changes of Hxx yield demonstrated that no reaction progressed after hot filtration. FT-IR spectrum of the spent Pd-0.5PEG2000/DMSNs was collected, and the data are compared with that of the fresh catalyst in Fig. 10 a. The spectra of Pd-0.5PEG2000/DMSNs before and after reaction are nearly identical, demonstrating its stable structure in the reaction. XPS spectrum of the spent Pd-0.5PEG2000/DMSNs was measured. As displayed in Fig. 10b, the content of coordinated Pd(0) was 22.90% after reaction, which is a little lower than that of the fresh catalyst (28.19%). In addition, the content of Pd(II) (10.0%) in the used Pd-0.5PEG2000/DMSNs was almost the same as that in the fresh catalyst (9.8%). Therefore, the good stability and reusability of Pd-0.5PEG2000/DMSNs can be well explained. In addition, ICP-OES analysis showed that Pd content in Pd-0.5PEG2000/DMSNs was decreased slightly from 0.69% to 0.64% after reaction. It can be concluded that Pd leaching was successfully avoided in this system. Based the experimental results and the previous literature reports [16, 52, 63, 64], a possible reaction pathway for co-dimerization of NBD and QC on the catalyst of Pd-0.5PEG2000/DMSNs has been proposed as shown in Scheme 3 . PEG2000 interacts properly with Pd(0) complex and DMSNs. With the regulation of PEG2000, Pd(0) complex is stably loaded on the surface of DMSNs with well-maintained activity and selectivity. QC has a strong coordination ability due to its strained multiple cyclopropane rings and low ionization potential. Initially, QC coordinates with Pd(0) to form an intermediate (1a). In the presence of many NBD molecules with π-accepting ability, one NBD molecule will insert into 1a to form new intermediates, 2a and 2b, in which one CC bond in the cyclopropane ring of QC is broken. The reaction is initiated through association of NBD to the Pd(0) atom using one of its π-systems to form the corresponding 18 electron complex. Based on the results of product detection, the coordinated NBD only exists in the exo-configuration, while the coordinated QC has two configurations: exo- and endo-, corresponding to 2a and 2b, respectively. Then, CC bonds form between the absorbed QC and NBD, and 2a and 2b are decomposed to produce the dimer products with exo-exo configuration and exo-endo configuration, respectively. If the dimer products further insert into the active intermediate of 1a, four new coordination intermediates (3a-3d) are formed. The four intermediates can be decomposed to generate a variety of trimer products with different structures. For the production of high density fuels, 120 mL of Hxx with a purity of 98% was obtained as catalyzed by Pd-0.5PEG2000/DMSNs. Then, hydrogenation saturation of the Hxx was conducted on a Pd/Al2O3 catalyst. Corresponding saturated polycyclic alkane (HHxx) has been obtained, which can be used a high density fuel. Table 4 summarizes the physicochemical properties of HHxx. The density of HHxx is 1.07 g•cm−3, the mass value of which reaches 41.74 MJ/kg. The NHOC value of HHxx (44.66 MJ/L) is much higher than that of the current commercial high density fuel, JP-10 (39.32 MJ/L). However, HHxx possesses a freezing point of −28 °C and a viscosity of 190.61 mm2/s at −20 °C, demonstrating its poor low-temperature property. In subsequent studies, attempts will be made to improve low temperature performance of the fuel by compounding it with the oils with low-freezing point. 4 Conclusions In summary, fragile Pd(0) complex has been successfully loaded on DMSNs with well-maintained activity as mediated by PEG2000. The as-prepared catalyst (Pd-0.5PEG2000/DMSNs) was active and selective for NBD-QC co-dimerization. Compared with other silica supports, e.g., PS, SBA-15, pure silicon KIT-6, MCM-41 and solid silica spheres (300-500 nm), DMSNs provide suitable environment to achieve properly interaction with PEG and Pd2(dba)3 for stably loading active separated Pd(0) atoms. Additionally, both a long chain length and an adequate concentration of PEG are required for well maintaining the coordinated single-atom Pd(0). With the addition of 0.5 mL PEG2000 during loading Pd2(dba)3 on DMSNs, 28.19% of the coordinated single-atom Pd(0) species were retained. Meanwhile, the fraction of aggregated Pd(0) particles was decreased from 71.78% to 62.01%, and the content of Pd(II) was significantly decreased from 22.82% to 9.8%. Pd-0.5PEG2000/DMSNs exhibited good stability and reusability. During recycling, a NBD conversion of more than 20% was well maintained, the conversion of QC was kept at 95%−100%, and the selectivity of Hxx was kept at a value of more than 90%. For the production of high density fuels, 1.2 L of Hxx with a purity of 98% was obtained as catalyzed by Pd-0.5 PEG2000/DMSNs. After hydrogenation saturation of Hxx, the high energy density fuel of HHxx with good performance was successfully prepared. The NHOC value of HHxx (44.66 MJ/L) is much higher than that of the current commercial high density fuel, JP-10 (39.32 MJ/L). HHxx exhibits good application prospect as high energy-density fuel. coredata.dc:description: High energy-density hydrocarbon fuels are the key materials for aircraft to increase payload and expand flight distance. Under the catalysis of atomically dispersed Pd(0) complex, saturated hexacyclic exo-exo product with good fuel property can be synthesized via co-dimerization of norbornadiene (NBD) with quadricyclane (QC). But the fragile coordination state of homogeneous Pd(0) complex limited its application in fuel production. In this work, Pd(0) complex has been heterogeneously supported on silica support with the regulation of polyethylene glycol (PEG) to increase its stability and recyclability with limited sacrifice of the activity and dimer selectivity. The structure of silica support was tuned to achieve the proper interaction with PEG and Pd(0) complex. The chain length and concentration of PEG were adjusted to further optimize the state of Pd(0) complex on silica. The as-developed heterogeneous Pd(0) complex supported on dendritic mesoporous silica nanospheres regulated by PEG2000 exhibited superior performance for the production of high energy density fuel through selective NBD-QC co-dimerization.
coredata.dc:title: Heterogeneously supported active Pd(0) complex on silica mediated by PEG as efficient dimerization catalyst for the production of high energy density fuel
